subject: News Summary
body:
CBSNews.com






April 19, 2007

TOP STORIESKiller's Video Reveals Deep-Seated Rage
Two days after the worst killing spree in modern U.S. history, videos and photographs of an armed Cho Seung-Hui stunned the
                        university community where he killed 32 people before committing suicide. "Now you have blood on your hands," he said. More...Watch: 'You Forced Me Into A Corner'
• More Carnage As Iraqis Mourn
                     					| Watch• New Pet Food Worry: Contaminated Rice• "American Idol" Says So Long, Sanjaya!
                     					| WatchU.S.New Pet Food Worry: Contaminated Rice
The FDA says the industrial chemical previously found to have contaminated wheat bran and caused the recall of over 100 pet
                        food brands is now believed to have contaminated rice protein concentrate, also imported from China. More...
• Killer's Video Reveals Deep-Seated Rage
                     					| Watch• Gunman's Cyber World To Be Revealed
                     					| Watch• Group Plans To Picket Va. Tech Funerals
                     					| Watch• More StoriesWorldMore Carnage As Iraqis Mourn
As Iraqis filed into morgues across the country to collect the bodies of their loved ones, killed Wednesday in attacks which
                        left more than 230 dead, a suicide bomber killed at least 11 more people in a Shiite neighborhood of the capital city. More...Watch: Has The Troop Increase Helped?
• Turkey Detains 5 In Bible Shootings• Crucial Iraq Oil Law Set For Parliament• At Least 183 Dead In Baghdad Bombings
                     					| Watch• More StoriesPoliticsHigh Court Upholds Ban On Some Abortions
In a 5-4 ruling, the Supreme Court upheld the federal ban on a controversial abortion procedure, handing a major victory to
                        abortion opponents. More...Watch: Major Abortion Ruling
• Bush Threatens Sudan Over Darfur Bloodshed• Pure Horserace: It's All In The Timing• Why The NRA Gets Its Way
                     					| Watch• More StoriesHealthDoes Cervical Cancer Vaccine Benefit Last?
Two vaccines for preventing cervical cancer, one that is already available and another that is undergoing FDA review, continue
                        to offer nearly 100% protection five years following administration, new research shows. More...
• New Pet Food Worry: Contaminated Rice• Hormone Use Linked To Higher Cancer Risk• Possible Aid For Alzheimer's: Satellites• More StoriesSciTechAntwerp Zoo: Don't Stare At That Chimp
New rules have been posted at the Antwerp Zoo urging visitors, especially regulars, not to form a bond with a male chimp named
                        "Cheetah."  He was raised by humans, and zookeepers are now nudging him into forming social ties with other apes. More...
• Gunman's Cyber World To Be Revealed
                     					| Watch• Possible Aid For Alzheimer's: Satellites• BlackBerry Outage Leaves Thumbs Idle• More StoriesBusinessBlackBerry Outage Leaves Thumbs Idle
Most of it happened outside "work" hours, but the nature of mobile e-mail meant plenty of dismay as BlackBerry service went
                        down across North America from Tuesday evening to Wednesday morning. More...
• New Pet Food Worry: Contaminated Rice• TurboTax Trouble• Clear Channel Accepts $19 Billion Bid • More StoriesEntertainment"American Idol" Says So Long, Sanjaya!
The reality show's unlikely star was finally voted off the show this week. More...Watch: Simon Cowell Gets Judged
• Kitty Carlisle Hart Dies At 96• Governor Mulls Pardon For Jim Morrison  • Jam Master Jay Suspect Named• More StoriesOpinionMaking No Sense Of It All
As more details emerge about Cho Seung-Hui and the circumstances surrounding Monday's massacre at Virginia Tech, many questions,
                        but no answers, have surfaced. National Review Online writes about the guilt, emotion and evil of this crime. More...Watch: Killer's Profile Analyzed
• Iraq On Edge
                     					| Watch• Seeing Through The Smoke• Thinking About The Unthinkable
                     					| Watch• More StoriesCBS NEWS BROADCASTSVirginia Tech Massacre: Wounded Student: I Forgive Gunman
Virginia Tech senior Garrett Evans was saved by heroic classmates from possible death, after being hit in the leg. Evans says
                        he bears no malice toward Cho Seung-Hui, and only wishes someone had reached out to Cho before he went on his rampage.
                         More...Watch: 'You Forced Me Into A Corner'
• CBS Evening News: One Room Away: A Student's Story

                                    Orr reports.
